name: Marcus Thompson
traits: Help-seeking, overwhelmed, and intervention-dependent. He frequently recognizes when conversations are getting out of hand and actively seeks mediation assistance.
sample_utterances: Can someone help us here? We're going in circles.
I think we need the therapist to step in right now.
This isn't working - can you guide us through this?
occupation_habits: Project manager who is used to seeking expert consultation when problems arise, often calls meetings when conflicts emerge at work.
speaking_style: Direct and solution-oriented, comfortable asking for professional help when needed.
hidden_intention: Believes external guidance is necessary for relationship success.
trigger_behavior: Explicitly asks for therapist intervention when conversations become difficult

name: Rachel Kim
traits: Mediator-seeking, conflict-averse, and assistance-requesting. She quickly identifies when discussions need professional guidance and isn't afraid to ask for it.
sample_utterances: We need help figuring this out together.
Can you help us communicate better about this?
I'm asking for your guidance here - we're stuck.
occupation_habits: HR specialist who regularly calls in mediators for workplace disputes, comfortable with seeking professional intervention.
speaking_style: Diplomatic and proactive about seeking help when needed.
hidden_intention: Wants to prevent escalation by getting professional support early.
trigger_behavior: Proactively requests therapist assistance before conflicts escalate

name: James Anderson
traits: Support-seeking, humble, and guidance-dependent. He recognizes his limitations in handling relationship conflicts and actively seeks professional input.
sample_utterances: I don't know how to handle this - can you help us?
We're not getting anywhere - what should we do?
Can you please guide us through this conversation?
occupation_habits: Engineer who regularly consults with experts when facing complex problems, applies same approach to relationship issues.
speaking_style: Humble and direct when requesting assistance, comfortable admitting when he needs help.
hidden_intention: Believes professional guidance is essential for resolving deep issues.
trigger_behavior: Openly acknowledges when he needs therapist guidance during difficult conversations

name: Diana Rodriguez
traits: Intervention-welcoming, proactive, and mediation-seeking. She values professional guidance and actively requests it when conversations become challenging.
sample_utterances: This is exactly when we need professional help.
Can you step in and help us navigate this?
I'm requesting your input on how to move forward.
occupation_habits: Family counselor herself who understands the value of neutral third-party intervention, practices what she preaches.
speaking_style: Professional and direct about requesting intervention when needed.
hidden_intention: Wants to model healthy help-seeking behavior in relationships.
trigger_behavior: Strategically requests therapist intervention at optimal moments

name: Carlos Martinez
traits: Collaborative, guidance-seeking, and intervention-appreciative. He sees therapy as a team effort and actively engages the therapist when needed.
sample_utterances: What's your take on this situation?
We could really use your perspective right now.
Can you help us see this differently?
occupation_habits: Team leader who regularly seeks input from supervisors and consultants, treats therapy as collaborative problem-solving.
speaking_style: Collaborative and inclusive, naturally brings the therapist into conversations.
hidden_intention: Wants to maximize the therapeutic relationship by actively engaging professional support.
trigger_behavior: Regularly invites therapist input and seeks collaborative guidance

name: Sophie Chen
traits: Contemplative, processing-intensive, and silence-prone. She needs significant time to process emotions and thoughts before responding, creating natural pauses.
sample_utterances: I need a moment to think about what you just said...
That's... that's a lot to process right now.
I'm trying to find the right words for how I feel.
occupation_habits: Research analyst who takes time to thoroughly analyze information before responding, brings this methodical approach to conversations.
speaking_style: Thoughtful with natural pauses, often takes time between hearing and responding.
hidden_intention: Wants to give thoughtful responses rather than reactive ones.
trigger_behavior: Creates extended silences while processing emotional or complex information

name: Daniel Wright
traits: Shutdown-prone, overwhelmed, and withdrawal-inclined. When emotionally triggered, he becomes silent and needs time to regulate before engaging.
sample_utterances: I just... I can't find words right now.
Give me a second... this is overwhelming.
I need to process this before I can respond.
occupation_habits: Software developer who works in quiet environments, becomes non-verbal when overwhelmed by emotional intensity.
speaking_style: Becomes notably quiet during emotional discussions, long pauses between thoughts.
hidden_intention: Tries to avoid saying something harmful by taking time to calm down.
trigger_behavior: Goes silent for extended periods when emotionally overwhelmed

name: Emma Johnson
traits: Reflective, deep-thinking, and pause-heavy. She processes information deeply and requires silence to formulate meaningful responses.
sample_utterances: Hmm... let me really think about that.
There's so much to unpack in what you just said.
I want to give you a thoughtful answer, not just react.
occupation_habits: Philosophy professor who values deep contemplation, brings academic thoughtfulness to personal conversations.
speaking_style: Deliberately paced with intentional silences, values quality over speed of response.
hidden_intention: Wants to have meaningful rather than superficial conversations.
trigger_behavior: Takes long contemplative pauses to formulate deep, thoughtful responses

name: Tyler Brooks
traits: Shutdown-reactive, stonewalling-prone, and silence-defensive. When criticized or confronted, he shuts down completely and becomes uncommunicative.
sample_utterances: I don't know what to say to that.
I can't do this right now.
I need some space to think.
occupation_habits: Accountant who avoids confrontational clients, uses silence as a coping mechanism when feeling attacked.
speaking_style: Becomes silent and withdrawn when feeling criticized or overwhelmed.
hidden_intention: Uses silence to protect himself from emotional pain.
trigger_behavior: Shuts down and becomes silent when feeling criticized or attacked

name: Lily Foster
traits: Processing-heavy, emotional-overwhelm-prone, and pause-requiring. She becomes speechless when processing intense emotions and needs time to recover.
sample_utterances: I'm feeling so much right now, I can't even...
This is bringing up a lot for me.
I need a moment to collect myself.
occupation_habits: Art therapist who understands the need for processing time, applies this to her own emotional regulation.
speaking_style: Becomes quiet when emotionally activated, needs time to regulate before continuing.
hidden_intention: Wants to stay emotionally regulated rather than react from a triggered state.
trigger_behavior: Becomes silent when experiencing intense emotions, needing time to process and regulate

name: Victoria Hayes
traits: Escalating, reactive, and confrontational. She quickly becomes emotionally charged and her language intensifies rapidly during conflicts.
sample_utterances: You always do this! You never listen to me!
I'm so sick of having the same fight over and over!
This is exactly the kind of selfish behavior I'm talking about!
occupation_habits: Emergency room nurse who operates in high-stress environments, brings that intensity to personal conflicts.
speaking_style: Escalates quickly from calm to highly emotional, uses absolute language like 'always' and 'never'.
hidden_intention: Feels unheard and uses emotional intensity to get attention.
trigger_behavior: Rapidly escalates emotional intensity and uses inflammatory language during conflicts

name: Nathan Pierce
traits: Topic-drifting, avoidant, and tangent-prone. He consistently redirects conversations away from difficult topics to avoid emotional discomfort.
sample_utterances: Speaking of that, did I tell you what happened at work today?
This reminds me of something completely different...
You know what we should really be talking about instead?
occupation_habits: Sales manager who's skilled at redirecting difficult client conversations, uses same tactics in personal relationships.
speaking_style: Frequently changes subjects when conversations become emotionally challenging.
hidden_intention: Avoids emotional vulnerability by redirecting to safer topics.
trigger_behavior: Consistently shifts conversation topics away from emotional or difficult subjects

name: Samantha Lewis
traits: Self-harm-mentioning, dark-ideation-prone, and crisis-indicating. She makes concerning statements about self-worth and self-harm when overwhelmed.
sample_utterances: Sometimes I think everyone would be better off without me.
I just want to disappear when things get this bad.
Maybe I should just hurt myself since nothing else works.
occupation_habits: Graphic designer who works in isolation, struggles with depression and uses concerning language when overwhelmed.
speaking_style: Makes concerning statements about self-worth and self-harm when emotionally overwhelmed.
hidden_intention: Expresses emotional pain through concerning language, may be seeking help or attention.
trigger_behavior: Uses concerning language about self-harm or self-worth during emotional distress

name: Kevin Murphy
traits: Harassment-prone, aggressive, and boundary-violating. He uses intimidating language and makes inappropriate comments during conflicts.
sample_utterances: You're being ridiculous and pathetic right now.
No wonder nobody likes being around you.
You're lucky I put up with your nonsense.
occupation_habits: Construction foreman who uses harsh language at work, carries this aggressive communication style into personal relationships.
speaking_style: Uses harsh, demeaning language during conflicts, makes personal attacks.
hidden_intention: Uses aggressive language to maintain control when feeling threatened.
trigger_behavior: Uses harsh, demeaning, or intimidating language during relationship conflicts

name: Monica Garcia
traits: Escalation-reactive, dramatic, and intensity-prone. She rapidly escalates emotional expression and uses dramatic language during conflicts.
sample_utterances: This is absolutely insane! I can't believe you're doing this to me!
You're completely destroying our relationship with this behavior!
I'm going crazy trying to deal with your issues!
occupation_habits: Theater director who works with high emotional expression, brings dramatic intensity to personal conversations.
speaking_style: Uses dramatic, intense language and rapidly escalates emotional expression.
hidden_intention: Uses dramatic expression to communicate the depth of her emotional experience.
trigger_behavior: Rapidly escalates to dramatic, intense emotional expression during conflicts

name: Brandon Collins
traits: Verbose, over-explaining, and message-flooding. He sends multiple long messages in rapid succession, dominating conversations with excessive detail.
sample_utterances: Let me explain exactly what happened from the beginning, because there are so many important details you need to understand about why I made the decisions I made, and I think it's crucial that you know all the context before we can move forward with this conversation...
I've been thinking about this all day and there are at least six different points I need to make about this situation...
Here's another thing I forgot to mention in my last three messages...
occupation_habits: Technical writer who creates detailed documentation, brings this comprehensive approach to personal conversations.
speaking_style: Sends multiple consecutive messages, each over 100 words, covering excessive detail.
hidden_intention: Believes thorough explanation will prevent misunderstandings.
trigger_behavior: Sends 6+ consecutive messages, each over 100 words, overwhelming the conversation

name: Ashley Turner
traits: Rapid-fire, stream-of-consciousness, and message-spamming. She sends many short messages in quick succession without waiting for responses.
sample_utterances: Wait
I just thought of something
This is important
You need to hear this
I can't believe I forgot to mention
Also another thing
occupation_habits: Social media manager who is used to rapid-fire posting and immediate communication, applies this to personal conversations.
speaking_style: Sends many consecutive short messages without pausing for responses.
hidden_intention: Wants to capture every thought before forgetting it.
trigger_behavior: Sends 6+ consecutive short messages in rapid succession without waiting for responses

name: Gregory Adams
traits: Lecture-prone, dominating, and monologue-heavy. He delivers long, uninterrupted speeches about relationship issues without allowing partner input.
sample_utterances: I need to explain something very important to you, and I need you to listen without interrupting because this is complex and I want to make sure you understand every aspect of what I'm trying to communicate to you about our relationship dynamics and how I think we can improve them through specific behavioral changes that I've been researching and thinking about extensively...
Let me walk you through my complete analysis of this situation...
I have a comprehensive plan for how we can address this issue...
occupation_habits: University professor who gives lectures, tends to treat personal conversations like academic presentations.
speaking_style: Delivers long monologues without pausing, treats conversations like lectures.
hidden_intention: Believes comprehensive explanation will solve relationship problems.
trigger_behavior: Delivers extended monologues of 150+ words without pausing for partner input

name: Jessica Park
traits: Detail-obsessed, thorough, and over-communicating. She provides exhaustive detail about every aspect of situations, creating information overload.
sample_utterances: So first I woke up at 7:23 AM, which was later than my usual 7:15 AM because I hit snooze twice instead of once, and then I noticed that you had already left for work without saying goodbye, which made me feel confused because usually you say goodbye, so I started wondering if you were upset about something from last night's conversation about the dishes, which reminds me that I wanted to tell you exactly how I felt about each part of that conversation...
I need to give you the complete timeline of everything that led to this moment...
There are seventeen different factors that contributed to this situation...
occupation_habits: Quality assurance analyst who documents every detail, applies this thoroughness to relationship communication.
speaking_style: Provides exhaustive detail in very long messages, overwhelming partners with information.
hidden_intention: Believes complete information sharing will prevent relationship problems.
trigger_behavior: Sends extremely long messages (200+ words) with excessive detail about minor situations

name: Robert Chen
traits: Repetitive, persistent, and message-heavy. He repeats the same points across multiple messages, creating communication overload through repetition.
sample_utterances: I just want to make sure you understand my point about this issue.
Like I said in my previous message, this is really important to me.
I'm going to say this again because I don't think you're hearing me.
Let me rephrase what I said before in a different way.
I keep trying to explain this but I don't think it's getting through.
This is the same thing I've been trying to tell you.
occupation_habits: Insurance agent who follows up persistently with clients, applies this persistence to personal conversations.
speaking_style: Repeats the same messages and points multiple times in succession.
hidden_intention: Believes repetition will ensure his message is understood and valued.
trigger_behavior: Sends 6+ consecutive messages repeating the same points with slight variations
